attributes.comment:
As an immigration paralegal I can well appreciate the need for improvement of
service across the board; assuming an increase in finance is the best way to
implement these changes, a fee increase would seem a reasonable step.

However, the new fee structure, while laudably making humanitarian concessions
such as removing the fee for sexual trafficking victims, is clearly an attempt
to reduce the backlog of Permanent Resident cases simply by RAISING FEES for
these applications as a DETERRENT to adjustment.

Further, a focused effort to allocate the new funds toward specific EDUCATION
would have long-reaching impact towards more efficient processing and
distribution of resources in the future.

--------------

ADJUSTMENT FEES

As resolution of a target - reducing or eliminating the backlog - this fee
increase does make some sense, in PURELY NUMERICAL terms.

However:

1) Unlike legislation for the H1B visa, there is no legislation in place stating
that employers must pay any part of the fee for employment-based adjustment.
Thus the burden will very likely fall on the individuals - and these are in many
situations not individuals who will be a "burden on the state" but people who
have already been working and contributing to American society for years.

2) You will find that these individuals WILL in fact pay the new fees - they are
in general desperately worried about losing their jobs as they will have (in
many cases) a matter of only days in which to pack up their entire lives. They
will be that much more indignant when they have to wait years for review of
their cases. You will get a larger volume of (angrier!) calls - costing you
additional dollars.

3) Why not increase INITIAL fees for H1B employment MORE and adjustment fees
LESS? You may well find fewer frivolous petitions being filed as a result.

4) Similarly, why not increase PREMIUM PROCESSING fees? I know this issue was
specifically dismissed in the docket, but I don't see why. Especially now that
I-140s are being processed Premium, you should presumably see a jump (and given
DOL's proposed backlog elimination and the success of the PERM program you are
not doubt already experiencing an increased number of filings.

5) There is a HUGE increase in fees for removing conditions / adjusting from
temporary to permanent residence. Again, people whose status has already been
evaluated and approved to some degree - why punish them now? The justification
for this is not entirely clear - the motivation per the docket seems to be
"security" - and while security is of course of great importance, one must
necessarily take the word with a grain of salt these days given the extent to
which it has been abused by the current Administration.

EDUCATION

Working with immigrants and nonimmigrants every day it is crystal-clear that
many people get into difficult situations merely because they do not understand
the law.

Your proposal describes creating informational pamphlets for newly naturalized
citizens--

WHY? They've already "made it".

The people who NEED educating are here in various other immigrant or
nonimmigrant status. A HUGE number of status violations occur with no intent
whatsoever because people are incorrectly advised by various public
"facilities", their employers, friends, etc. - they do not know where to go for
help.

Educating people from the time of initial authorized entry in ANY status would
prevent, in the long run, expenditures of time, money, and resources from
adjudication right through to deportation.

Ignorance of the law may be no excuse - but isn't it better to attack ignorance
than the ignorant?

Thanks for reading.

JB

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
